attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
A physical stock take was conducted on 4 March 2025 to assess whether the physical stock counted matched with the book balance.

It was noted that there were minimal variations between the counted physical and the book stocks in most items except: -

v  Poly bags had cumulative variance of +132 pieces

v  Bread stock had a short fall of 133.25loaves.

v  White ingredients 18Kg and 9kg had a variation of +1.15 bags & -1.8 bags respectively

v  White flour had a positive variation of 25kg

The table below illustrates the findings.
attributes.recommendation:
The branch needs to tighten stock controls to reduce the variations noted packing materials

The accounts department should correct the BOM to reflect the actual production.
attributes.effect: Weak controls were noted on most of the stock items resulting to significant loss.

value: Stock variations noted were due to poor recording of mixing charts and mixing chart summary and also error on the BOM for Super loaf and Naivas products which have a different BOM but yield is the same on similar products.
Will make follow up for naivas to avoid the variations

In a prior report dated 09th February 2025 it was noted that most stock items had nil variations with exception to bread stock which had a variance of -235pcs, White flour which had  appositive variation of 33.53kg and poly bags +851pcs.
Previous

attributes.title: Bread Weight
attributes.description:
A sample of bread produced and packed in the branch were randomly selected and weighed. The aim was to check whether bread sent to the market were of the minimum weight as set by the KEBS.

Case of underweight were noted on 400CTW, 600 BW and 200 ML. The table below illustrates the findings: -
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should enhance the frequency of checks at the dividing table to ensure that the dividers adhere to the dividing range
attributes.effect: The underweight should be discouraged since it may cost the company unnecessary fines due to non-compliance to laid down standards of operation as per the regulatory body (KEBS).

value: We are working well and endeavor to maintain good weights and correct the few underweight.
Noted, will do more in samplings to control the weight
During the prior audit underweight were noted across all the varieties sampled.
Previous

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of production and market damages was done to determine whether bread damages were within the allowed percentage of 0.20% to total production and 0.50% of total sales.

The audit sample period was the month of February 25. The flowing were the findings: -

v  Production Damages were averaging at 0.32% of the total production

v  Marker damages stood at 0.38% of the total sales which was within the allowable percentage of 0.50%.

The table below illustrates details of the findings: -

 

Table 1 Analysis of Production Damages

         Table 2 Analysis of Market Damages
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should control damages by ensuring that all production procedures are being followed and produce bread of good quality so as to reduce production damages.
attributes.effect:
Production damages slightly surpassed the set limit of 0.20% by 0.12%. This resulted to a revenue loss of Ksh.71,006.50

Market damages were within the set limit of 0.5%.

value: We are trying our best to reduce bread damages in the branch by ensuring we produce quality bread. And in some cases oven breakdown and borrowed bread contributes to high damages
Compared to last audit branch has improved on damage control.
During the prior audit it was noted that production damages were 0.30% of the total production while market damages were 0.38% of the total sales.
Previous

attributes.title: Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis
attributes.description:
Bread damages sent to ingredients were computed to establish whether damages sent match with damages captured on the SAP systems. The audit period was from 1 February 2025 to 28 February 2025.

There was no noted significant difference between total damages at the branch level and damages sent to ingredients damages. Total branch damages were 7,780.50 pieces while those sent to ingredients were 7,810.75 pieces, resulting in a variance of 30.25 pieces of bread.

Below is summary of the findings: -
attributes.recommendation: Branch management to put measures in place to weigh and verify all daily damages broken and sent to ingredients so as to reflect the accurate status of declared and available damages
attributes.effect: The excess damages sent to ingredients implies weak control on recording of damages.

value: We will maintain proper records for bread damages so to reduce variance of damages in the branch and sent
Within the limit
During the prior audit it was noted that damages sent to ingredients had a negligible variance of 24 loaves
Previous

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
An analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summary were done for a period of 32 days from 1 February 2025 to 4 March 2025.

Below is summary of the findings.

v  Utto consumption stood at 100 %.

v  Average yield was 192.74 loaves per bag.

v  Average production was 182.59 bags per day this represent 93.64% of the set target of 180 bags.

v  35 cases of remix were noted.

The table shows the summary findings of the mixing chart
attributes.recommendation: The branch should strive to ensure that they attain their target.
attributes.effect: Production target was not met meaning the branch had some idle capacity resulting unabsorbed fixed cost and other opportunity costs.

value: Production is affected by low sales that prompts to shift cuts in order to control bread balanceProduction is affected by low sales that prompts to shift cuts in order to control bread balance
Low sales contributed
In prior audit production target was averaged at 182.5 bags per day
Previous

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
A spot check in the cash office was carried out with the aim of ensuring cash at hand was tallying with that of the cash flow balance.

It was noted that the cashier fully accounted for the expected cash balance of Ksh 32,332 as at 6 March 2025.

At the time of the audit Iou’s which were pending was amounted to Ksh. 12,800. It was also noted that the Iou’s were not cleared with the 3 days as required. The table below illustrated the details of the IOUs.
attributes.recommendation:
·         The cashier should maintain the controls.

·         Branch management needs to ensure iou’s are cleared within the set period.
attributes.effect:
Company’s money was adequately safeguarded.

Ious should be cleared within the 3 days as per the company policy

value: Cash was well controlled
Cash was okay.
It was noted that the cashier accounted for all the cash balance
